security_analysis.explanation: The URL contains phishing keywords like "login", "verify", "secure", "admin", "account", "update".

security_analysis.explanation: The website uses HTTP instead of HTTPS — meaning the connection is NOT encrypted.
security_analysis.risk: Everything you type on this site (passwords, card numbers) is sent in plain text. Anyone on the same network can intercept it.

security_analysis.risk: This URL has a documented history of hosting malicious or deceptive content according to threat databases.

security_analysis.explanation: The domain/hostname part of the URL is very long.
security_analysis.risk: Long hostnames are used to embed fake brand names (like "paypal.secure-login.com") to fool users into thinking they are on a real site.

security_analysis.explanation: The URL uses a raw IP address (like 192.168.1.1) instead of a domain name.
security_analysis.risk: Real websites almost never use raw IP addresses. Attackers use IPs to avoid domain blacklists and hide their identity.

security_analysis.explanation: The URL contains an unusually large number of dots (.).
security_analysis.risk: More dots mean more subdomains. Attackers stack subdomains like "apple.paypal.secure.login.evil.com" to make fake sites look real.

security_analysis.explanation: The URL contains many hyphens (-).
security_analysis.risk: Multiple hyphens are used as visual tricks to make fake domains look like real brand names at a quick glance.

security_analysis.explanation: The URL contains percent-encoded characters (%) used to hide its true content.
security_analysis.risk: Percent encoding can disguise malicious characters, bypass URL filters, or hide the real destination of a redirect.

security_analysis.explanation: The website uses HTTP instead of HTTPS — meaning the connection is NOT encrypted.
security_analysis.risk: Everything you type on this site (passwords, card numbers) is sent in plain text. Anyone on the same network can intercept it.

security_analysis.explanation: The website uses a top-level domain (TLD) commonly associated with phishing attacks (e.g. .tk, .ml, .xyz, .win, .click).
security_analysis.risk: Many free or very cheap TLDs are heavily abused by attackers because they require no identity verification and cost almost nothing.
